persona_description: Jasmine is a 29-year-old cashier with a high school diploma living in rural West Virginia with a lower-middle income. She is unmarried and has Medicaid coverage. Jasmine is moderately health-conscious, gets regular checkups, and has well-controlled asthma. This is her first pregnancy (G1P0), and she is uncertain about her pregnancy plans, not taking prenatal vitamins.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
# Medical Research Interview

Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today, Jasmine. I really appreciate your willingness to participate in this research. 

Before we dive in, I want you to know that this is a safe, confidential space. There are no right or wrong answers—I'm just here to understand your experiences and perspectives. If any question feels too personal or you'd prefer not to answer, just let me know and we can skip it.

Let me start with some background information to get to know you better.

**To begin, can you tell me a little bit about yourself? What's been going on in your life recently, particularly around your pregnancy?**

I noticed from your health records that this is your first pregnancy. How are you feeling about that overall? And when did you find out you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
# Jasmine's Response

*shifts in seat and takes a breath*

Yeah, well... it's been a lot, honestly. I'm 29, been working as a cashier at the local grocery store for about five years now. It's part-time work, so the income's not always steady, but we get by. My husband and I have been married for three years now, and we live here in Beckley—been here my whole life, pretty much.

*pauses, looking down at hands*

As for the pregnancy... I found out about two months ago. It was kind of a shock, to be honest. We weren't exactly planning it, but we weren't preventing it either, if that makes sense? My husband was excited right away, but I've been... I don't know, uncertain about it all. There's a lot going through my head.

*fidgets slightly*

Life's been pretty stressful lately. Work can be demanding—dealing with customers, the scheduling is unpredictable. And honestly, I feel kind of isolated sometimes out here. A lot of my friends have moved away, and my family situation is complicated. My husband's been supportive, but he works long hours too, so we don't always have time to talk things through.

*looks up*

I have Medicaid, which is good because I don't know how we'd afford all this otherwise. I've had my regular checkups—I'm pretty good about that usually, even with my asthma. But with the pregnancy... I haven't really started prenatal vitamins yet. I know I probably should, but I'm just... still processing everything, I guess.

Is that the kind of information you were looking for?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods and settles back in chair*

Yeah, so like I mentioned, I found out about two months ago. It was actually kind of by accident, if I'm being honest. I'd been feeling a little off—tired, nauseous in the mornings—and I just thought maybe it was stress or something with my asthma acting up. I wasn't really thinking pregnancy.

*rubs arms*

But then I was late, and my husband suggested I take a test. I was skeptical at first, but... yeah, it came back positive. I took two actually, just to be sure. And then I made an appointment with my doctor to confirm it.

*pauses, looking uncertain*

This is my first pregnancy—my first time going through anything like this. So honestly, I didn't really know what to expect. I'm still kind of... wrapping my head around it all, you know?

*fidgets with hands*

The timing just feels complicated. With my job being part-time and the income being unpredictable, and with everything else going on... I guess I'm still trying to figure out if I'm ready for this. My husband's on board, but it's me who has to go through it all, and sometimes that feels overwhelming.

*looks at interviewer*

I know I should probably be more excited or prepared by now, but I'm just being honest—I'm still uncertain about a lot of things. Is that normal? Do other women feel this way when they find out?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*shifts uncomfortably and takes a moment before responding*

Well, like I said, after I confirmed the pregnancy with the home tests, I called my doctor's office to set up an appointment. That was probably about a week after I found out. I have a regular doctor I see for my asthma checkups, so I called them first.

*frowns slightly*

The appointment took a while to get—I think it was about three weeks out. They were pretty busy. When I finally went in, the doctor confirmed everything, did some basic stuff, asked me questions about my medical history, my family history, that kind of thing. They talked about my asthma and made sure my medications were safe during pregnancy, which was good to know.

*pauses, looking a bit hesitant*

But honestly? The experience felt kind of... rushed, I guess? The appointment was maybe 20 minutes total. They gave me some pamphlets about prenatal care and mentioned vitamins, but nobody really sat down and explained things to me in detail. I had questions, but I felt like they were busy and I didn't want to hold things up.

*looks down*

They did mention I should start prenatal vitamins with folic acid, and they scheduled me for an ultrasound and some lab work. But I haven't actually filled the vitamin prescription yet. Part of it is the cost—I wasn't sure if my Medicaid would cover it—and part of it is just... I don't know, I haven't gotten around to it.

*meets interviewer's eyes*

Is that something I really need to start right away? I'm still in my first trimester, right?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*settles back and thinks for a moment*

So right now, it's my regular doctor—Dr. Patterson. He's been my doctor for maybe four or five years now, mostly for my asthma management and regular checkups. He's... he's fine, I guess. Professional. He knows my medical history, which is helpful. But he's not an OB-GYN or anything—he's just a general practitioner.

*fidgets with the hem of her shirt*

I mean, he's handling my prenatal care so far, but honestly, I'm not entirely sure if that's the best setup. He referred me to get an ultrasound done at the hospital, and they mentioned something about potentially seeing a midwife or an OB down the road, but nothing's been scheduled yet. It's all kind of unclear to me.

*looks uncertain*

As for my relationship with him... I don't know. He's competent, I think. But like I said, the appointments feel rushed. I don't feel like there's a lot of time to really talk through my concerns or my uncertainty about the pregnancy. He seems more focused on the medical checklist—vitamins, tests, that sort of thing—rather than, like, how I'm actually feeling about all this emotionally.

*pauses*

And I guess part of me is wondering if I should be seeing someone who specializes in pregnancy? I'm not really sure what the standard is out here in West Virginia. Are there better options I should be looking into?

*looks at interviewer with a mix of curiosity and concern*

What do you think? Should I be pushing for a referral to someone else?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*sighs and leans forward slightly*

Well, so far I've only had the one appointment I mentioned—that initial confirmation visit with Dr. Patterson about a month ago. They scheduled me for a follow-up, but that's not until next month sometime. I have the appointment card somewhere, but I'm not exactly sure of the exact date off the top of my head.

*rubs face tiredly*

As for what a typical visit is like... honestly, based on that first one, I'm not sure what "typical" even looks like yet. But let me walk you through what happened:

*counts on fingers*

I checked in at the front desk, waited maybe 15 minutes in the waiting room. Then a nurse took me back, checked my blood pressure, weight, asked some basic questions about how I was feeling. That was maybe five minutes. Then Dr. Patterson came in, asked me a bunch of questions about my medical history, family history, whether I was taking any medications besides my asthma inhaler.

*pauses*

He did a physical exam—checked my abdomen, listened to my heart and lungs. Asked about my asthma symptoms, made sure I was still using my inhaler correctly. Then he talked about the vitamins again, mentioned I need to avoid certain things, gave me those pamphlets.

*looks down*

He ordered lab work and the ultrasound, wrote down some referrals, and then... that was pretty much it. The whole thing felt like maybe 20, 25 minutes tops.

*looks up with concern*

I'm not sure if that's normal or if I should be getting more time and attention? And I'm honestly not sure what to expect at the next visit. Will it be different? Should I be preparing questions or something?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*shifts uncomfortably and nods slowly*

Yeah, actually. I had a urinary tract infection a few weeks ago—a pretty bad one. I think they called it acute cystitis or something like that. I had pain when I was urinating, and I was going to the bathroom constantly. It was really uncomfortable and kind of scary because I wasn't sure if it would affect the baby.

*rubs lower abdomen*

I called Dr. Patterson's office about it, and they got me in pretty quickly, which was good. He prescribed me an antibiotic that he said was safe during pregnancy. It cleared up after a few days, thank goodness. But that whole experience made me realize how little I actually know about what's normal and what's not during pregnancy.

*pauses, looking worried*

Besides that... I've had the nausea I mentioned, especially in the mornings. Some days it's worse than others. I'm tired a lot too—like, exhausted. I can barely get through my shift at work sometimes. I'm not sure if that's normal or if something's wrong.

*fidgets with hands*

And honestly, the stress and anxiety have been getting to me. I lie awake at night sometimes just thinking about everything—the pregnancy, money, whether I'm ready for this. I don't know if that's affecting the baby or if I should talk to someone about it.

*looks at interviewer with concern*

Are these things I should be more worried about? Should I be calling my doctor more often? I don't want to be that person who's always calling with questions, but I'm also worried about missing something important.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and looks a bit sheepish*

Well, like I mentioned earlier, I'm supposed to be taking prenatal vitamins with folic acid, but... I haven't actually started them yet. The prescription is sitting at home, I think. I just haven't gotten around to filling it, or maybe I did fill it but haven't started taking them regularly. I'm not entirely sure, to be honest.

*rubs back of neck*

For my asthma, I take an albuterol inhaler—the rescue inhaler—when I need it. I don't have a daily controller medication right now because my asthma has been pretty well-controlled. Dr. Patterson checked on that at my prenatal appointment and said the albuterol should be fine to keep using during pregnancy, so that's good.

*counts on fingers*

I think that's... that's actually it. I'm not on any other medications or supplements. No blood pressure meds or anything like that. My asthma's the only ongoing condition I really have.

*looks uncertain*

But now I'm wondering if I should be taking something else? Like, are there other supplements besides the prenatal vitamins that I should be on? And I'm still not totally clear on whether my Medicaid covers the prenatal vitamins or if there's a cost to me. That's part of why I haven't started them yet—I wasn't sure what the financial situation would be.

*meets interviewer's eyes*

Should I be more proactive about getting started on those vitamins? I know folic acid is important, especially early on. How urgent is it at this point?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and thinks for a moment*

Oh, um... well, I guess I haven't really changed my diet that much since finding out I was pregnant. I mean, I'm eating, obviously, but I'm not sure I'm doing it "right," you know?

*shifts in seat*

A typical day for me... I usually skip breakfast or just grab coffee because I'm rushing to get ready for work. Then at work, I'll grab something from the break room—maybe a sandwich or some chips. Lunch is usually whatever's convenient, honestly. Sometimes I'll eat something from the deli at the grocery store where I work, sometimes I just pack a sandwich from home.

*looks down*

Dinner is... it depends. My husband and I try to cook when we can, but between his work schedule and mine, it's not always consistent. We do a lot of pasta, chicken, stuff that's easy to throw together. We eat out sometimes too when we're both tired, which is probably more often than we should.

*fidgets*

I haven't really thought much about eating "for two" or anything like that. And with the nausea, some days I'm just trying to eat *anything* that doesn't make me feel sick. Crackers, toast, ginger ale—that kind of stuff.

*looks uncertain*

I know I should probably be eating healthier—more vegetables, fruits, that sort of thing. But honestly, between the cost and just trying to get through the day... I'm not sure what I'm supposed to be doing differently.

*meets interviewer's eyes*

Is my diet something I need to worry about right now? Should someone have given me more guidance on that?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a deep breath and looks down at hands, then back up*

Honestly? It's been... a lot. I think that's the best way to describe it.

*pauses, choosing words carefully*

Like I said before, I'm uncertain about the pregnancy itself. Part of me is trying to be excited because my husband is, and I know that's what I'm "supposed" to feel. But a lot of the time, I just feel... overwhelmed, I guess. Scared, sometimes.

*fidgets with hands*

There's the practical stuff—worrying about money, whether we can afford a baby on my part-time income, what happens with my job. Will I be able to take time off? Will they even hold my position? And then there's the bigger stuff—am I going to be a good mother? What if something goes wrong? What if I'm not ready?

*voice gets quieter*

And then there's the isolation piece. Like I mentioned, a lot of my friends have moved away, and out here in rural West Virginia, it's not like there are a ton of resources or support groups or anything. I feel kind of alone in this, even though my husband is supportive. He can't really understand what I'm going through physically and emotionally, you know?

*looks up with concern in eyes*

The stress has been getting worse, honestly. Some nights I can't sleep even though I'm exhausted. I just lie there thinking about everything. And then I worry that the stress is bad for the baby, which just makes me more stressed.

*pauses*

I haven't really talked to anyone about how I'm feeling—not my doctor, not really my husband in detail. I wasn't sure if it was normal or if I should be concerned about it. Is this something I should be addressing? Like, should I be talking to someone—a counselor or therapist or something?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a moment and looks thoughtful*

Well, my husband is definitely my main support. He's been excited about the pregnancy from the start, and he's been... he tries to be supportive, you know? He'll ask how I'm feeling, he's interested in the baby stuff. But honestly, we don't always have a lot of time to really talk things through because we're both working and tired.

*pauses, looking a bit sad*

Beyond that... it's kind of limited, to be honest. My family situation is complicated. My mom and I have a strained relationship—we don't talk very often. My dad passed away when I was younger, so he's not around. I have a couple of siblings, but we're not super close. They're scattered—one's in Ohio, one's in Virginia. We don't really keep in regular contact.

*fidgets with hands*

As for friends, like I mentioned, a lot of them have moved away over the years. People leave West Virginia looking for better job opportunities or just a change of scenery. I've got maybe one or two people I still talk to regularly, but we don't see each other that often. And I haven't really told many people about the pregnancy yet, partly because I'm still processing it myself.

*looks down*

My husband's family is around, but we're not particularly close with them either. His mom is okay, but we don't have that kind of relationship where I'd feel comfortable really opening up to her about my concerns and uncertainties.

*meets interviewer's eyes with concern*

So yeah... it's basically just my husband and me, really. Which is why I think the isolation is hitting me harder. There's not really anyone else I can talk to about what I'm going through—no other pregnant women, no experienced mothers I'm close to, no real community support.

*pauses*

Is that... is that a problem? Should I be trying to build more of a support network?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*looks a bit startled by the question and laughs nervously*

Oh, um... I haven't really thought that far ahead, to be honest. I'm still just trying to wrap my head around being pregnant, you know? Birth feels like something that's way off in the future.

*shifts uncomfortably*

I mean, I guess I've thought about it in a vague way—like, I know I'll have to give birth at some point, obviously. But as far as what that actually looks like or what I want... I don't really know what my options even are out here.

*looks uncertain*

Is it just hospital or home birth? Do I have choices about that? I assumed I'd go to the hospital because that seems like what most people do, but I'm not sure. And I don't even know what a "birth plan" really entails. Is that something I'm supposed to be working on now, or is that later?

*pauses, looking a bit overwhelmed*

Honestly, I haven't really had anyone explain all this to me. Dr. Patterson didn't really go into detail about delivery options or anything like that. The pamphlets they gave me have some information, but I haven't really read through them thoroughly.

*meets interviewer's eyes*

I guess... I don't know. I want it to be safe for the baby, obviously. And I want to minimize pain if possible, but I'm not sure what that means in practical terms. Do I need to be making decisions about this already? And who would I even talk to about it—Dr. Patterson, or should that be with an OB-GYN?

*looks genuinely confused*

What does a typical birth plan look like?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and thinks for a moment*

Well, honestly, I haven't been super proactive about seeking out information. I know I probably should be, but...

*fidgets*

Mainly, I've just looked stuff up on Google when I have a specific question or concern. Like, when I had the UTI, I googled "UTI during pregnancy" to see if it would hurt the baby. And I've looked up things like "is morning sickness normal" and "how much weight should I gain." That kind of thing.

*looks a bit sheepish*

I've also scrolled through some pregnancy stuff on Facebook—there are some groups, I think, but I haven't really joined any or participated. It just felt kind of... I don't know, intimidating? Like everyone else would know so much more than me.

*continues*

The pamphlets Dr. Patterson gave me are sitting at home, like I mentioned. I've glanced through them, but I haven't really sat down and read them thoroughly. They're kind of overwhelming, honestly—a lot of information all at once.

*pauses*

My husband's mom mentioned a pregnancy book she had when she was pregnant, and she offered to lend it to me, but I haven't actually taken her up on that yet.

*looks uncertain*

I haven't really watched any videos or taken any classes or anything like that. I didn't even know if those were available out here, to be honest. And I'm not sure where I'd find reliable information versus stuff that's just... wrong or alarmist.

*meets interviewer's eyes*

Is there stuff I should be reading or watching? What do you recommend?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a deep breath and looks down, clearly uncomfortable with the topic*

Oh man, yeah... that's one of the big things keeping me up at night, honestly.

*rubs face*

So, my husband and I... we're doing okay, I guess. We get by. But we're definitely not comfortable financially. My part-time cashier job brings in maybe... I don't know, around $1,200 a month? It varies depending on hours. My husband works full-time—he does construction—so his income is more stable, but it's not like we're rolling in money.

*fidgets with hands*

We have our bills—rent, utilities, groceries, gas. We manage those, but there's not a lot left over at the end of the month. And now thinking about a baby... it's terrifying, honestly.

*looks up with concern*

I haven't really started buying anything yet. No crib, no clothes, no diapers. I know I'm supposed to be preparing, but every time I think about the cost of all that stuff, I just... I don't know where to start. Diapers alone seem expensive, and then there's formula if I can't breastfeed, and car seats, and...

*voice gets quieter*

I have Medicaid, which covers the pregnancy and delivery, which is huge. I don't know what we'd do without it. But I'm not sure what else it covers—like, do they cover the baby's care after birth? Do they cover formula if I need it?

*pauses*

We've talked a little about me taking maternity leave, but I'm not sure if my part-time job even offers that. And if I'm not working, we lose that income, which is already tight. My husband might be able to pick up extra hours, but that means he'd be working even more.

*looks overwhelmed*

I haven't really looked into childcare costs either, but I'm pretty sure that's going to be expensive. Like, eventually I'd want to go back to work, but if childcare costs more than I make...

*meets interviewer's eyes*

Honestly, I'm not sure how we're going to make this work financially. Have I missed something? Are there resources or assistance programs I should know about?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*sighs heavily and leans back in chair*

Oh, that's... that's been complicated, honestly.

*pauses, choosing words carefully*

So, like I mentioned, I work part-time as a cashier at the grocery store. The hours are unpredictable—some weeks I get 20 hours, some weeks maybe 30. It depends on how busy they are and what the scheduling looks like. That inconsistency has always been stressful, but now with the pregnancy...

*rubs temples*

Physically, it's been harder. I'm on my feet for most of my shift, and between the fatigue and the nausea, some days I just feel wiped out. There was one day last week where I felt so dizzy I almost passed out at the register. That scared me—I was worried about what that meant for the baby.

*looks down*

And then there's the mental side of it. I'm constantly worried about what's going to happen when I start showing more, or when I need time off for appointments. My manager is... okay, I guess, but I'm not sure how understanding he'll be about needing flexibility.

*fidgets*

I haven't officially told my work yet that I'm pregnant. Part of me is worried they'll treat me differently or try to cut my hours. I know that's probably not legal or whatever, but I'm not sure what my rights are, and I don't want to rock the boat, you know?

*looks up with concern*

And then there's the bigger question—what happens after the baby is born? I need to work because we need the income, but I also need to be there for the baby. I don't even know what maternity leave looks like for part-time employees. Do I even get any? How long? Will my job be there when I come back?

*voice gets quieter*

I haven't really talked to anyone at work about any of this. I'm kind of just... trying to keep my head down and get through each day right now.

*meets interviewer's eyes*

Should I be doing something about this? Like, should I be talking to my manager or HR or something?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*laughs nervously and shakes head*

Honestly? No, not really. I know that sounds bad, but like... I'm still just trying to get through the pregnancy part. The postpartum stuff feels even further away and more overwhelming.

*pauses, looking uncertain*

I mean, I know intellectually that I'm going to have a baby and then I'm going to have to... take care of it, you know? But as far as actual planning? I haven't really thought that through.

*fidgets with hands*

I guess I'm assuming I'll be home for a little bit after birth, but like I said, I'm not even sure what my maternity leave situation is. And then what? Do I go back to work right away? Do I try to find childcare? I don't even know where I'd look for that out here.

*looks worried*

And then there's the whole... postpartum recovery thing. I don't really know what to expect. Like, how long does it take to recover? What am I supposed to do during that time? Can I be alone with the baby, or do I need help?

*rubs back of neck*

My husband will be around, I think. He said he'd try to take some time off work, but I'm not sure for how long. And like I mentioned, my family support isn't really there. So it would basically be me and my husband figuring it out.

*meets interviewer's eyes with concern*

I haven't thought about breastfeeding versus formula, or... I don't know, sleep schedules or any of that stuff. Should I be thinking about this already? Is there someone who's supposed to be helping me plan for all this?

*pauses*

Honestly, I feel like there's so much I don't know and no one's really explaining it to me.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods and looks relieved, though still somewhat anxious*

Yeah, of course. Thank you for listening, honestly. It's been... it's actually been kind of good to talk through all this out loud, even though it made me realize how unprepared I am for everything.

*stands up slowly*

I appreciate you taking the time to ask these questions. It's made me think about some things I probably should be addressing—like the prenatal vitamins, and maybe I need to talk to Dr. Patterson more, or find someone who specializes in pregnancy.

*pauses, looking thoughtful*

And maybe I should be looking into some of those resources you might have mentioned... or that I should be looking for. I'm going to try to do better about reaching out and getting more information instead of just... existing in this fog of uncertainty, you know?

*meets interviewer's eyes*

Is there anything else I should know? Or any resources you'd recommend I look into? I feel like I'm starting from scratch here, and honestly, any guidance would help.

*gathers belongings*

And if you need any follow-up information or want to check in again, I'm happy to do that. This was actually... helpful, I think. It's made me realize I need to be more proactive about my own care and about preparing for this baby.

*offers a small, grateful smile*

Thank you again for listening and for caring enough to ask these questions.

persona_traceability.description: Jasmine is a 29-year-old cashier with a high school diploma living in rural West Virginia with a lower-middle income. She is unmarried and has Medicaid coverage. Jasmine is moderately health-conscious, gets regular checkups, and has well-controlled asthma. This is her first pregnancy (G1P0), and she is uncertain about her pregnancy plans, not taking prenatal vitamins.
